meanings.def: moving or able to move quickly
examples: a fast car/horse
He's just become the world's fastest runner.
Her pulse seemed very fast.
She loves driving fast cars.

meanings.def: happening in a short time or without delay
examples: We've recorded the fastest rate of increase for several years.
We can guarantee a fast response time.
Technology was expanding at a fast pace.
a period of fast economic growth
a rapid train
We had a rapid coffee.
a swift decision
The government took swift action.
a speedy recovery
a speedy car.
I should make a very fast profit on these.
Viktor set the fastest lap time of the weekend.
I suppose delivery in two days is pretty fast, really.

meanings.def: able to do something quickly
examples: a fast learner
Are you a fast reader with the ability to retain the key points?
These are complex programs needing very large and fast computers.
a fast internet connection

meanings.def: producing or allowing quick movement
examples: It's a very fast road and people do not realize what speed they are doing.

meanings.def: showing a time later than the true time
examples: I'm early—my watch must be fast.
That clock's ten minutes fast.

meanings.def: very sensitive to light, and therefore useful when taking photographs in poor light or of something that is moving very quickly
safely fixed in position
examples: He made the boat fast.

meanings.def: not likely to change or to come out when washed
to be quick to understand or react in a new situation
examples: You can't fool him—he's always fast on the draw.

meanings.def: to be quick at pulling out a gun in order to shoot it
to be quick to understand or react in a new situation
examples: You can't fool him—he's always quick on the draw.

meanings.def: to be quick at pulling out a gun in order to shoot it
full of rapid action and sudden changes
examples: In his latest movie, the action is fast and furious.

meanings.def: a person who can talk very quickly and easily, but who cannot always be trusted
examples: As a politician, she had the reputation for being a real fast talker.

meanings.def: a person who knows how to get what they want quickly, especially when beginning a sexual relationship with somebody
that cannot be changed in any circumstances
examples: There are no hard and fast rules about this.
This situation isn’t hard and fast.

meanings.def: to earn money quickly and easily
examples: This is a long-term project. We are not out to make a quick buck.

meanings.def: to trick somebody

idioms.def: to be quick to understand or react in a new situation
examples: You can't fool him—he's always fast on the draw.

idioms.def: to be quick to understand or react in a new situation
examples: You can't fool him—he's always quick on the draw.

idioms.def: full of rapid action and sudden changes
examples: In his latest movie, the action is fast and furious.

idioms.def: a person who can talk very quickly and easily, but who cannot always be trusted
examples: As a politician, she had the reputation for being a real fast talker.

idioms.def: a person who knows how to get what they want quickly, especially when beginning a sexual relationship with somebody
that cannot be changed in any circumstances
examples: There are no hard and fast rules about this.
This situation isn’t hard and fast.

idioms.def: to earn money quickly and easily
examples: This is a long-term project. We are not out to make a quick buck.

meanings.def: quickly
examples: Don't drive so fast!
How fast were you going?
I can't go any faster.
The water was rising fast.
Her heart beat faster.
(formal) Night was fast approaching.
He came round the corner blindingly fast.
By a few easy steps you can make your PC run faster.
I quickly realized that I was on the wrong train.
My heart started to beat more quickly.
Come on! Quick! They’ll see us!
My heart started to beat much quicker.
The quicker I get you away from here, the better.
How fast can a cheetah run?
Can’t you drive any faster?
You’re driving too quickly.

meanings.def: in a short time; without delay
examples: Children grow up so fast these days.
Britain is fast becoming a nation of fatties.
The police said that they had reacted as fast as they could.
Ben knew he had to move fast.
The economy was expected to grow significantly faster than it did.

meanings.def: doing the thing mentioned quickly
examples: a fast-flowing stream
fast-growing crops
a fast-moving detective story

meanings.def: completely
examples: Within a few minutes she was fast asleep (= sleeping deeply).
The boat was stuck fast (= unable to move) in the mud.

meanings.def: as quickly as you can
to be disappearing quickly
examples: Hopes of a peace settlement were fading fast.

meanings.def: to continue to believe in an idea, etc. despite difficulties
to treat somebody/something in a way that shows that you feel no responsibility or respect for them
to refuse to move back; to refuse to change your opinions
quickly and in large quantities
examples: Questions were coming at them thick and fast.

idioms.idiom: as fast as your legs can carry you

examples: Hopes of a peace settlement were fading fast.

idioms.def: to continue to believe in an idea, etc. despite difficulties
to treat somebody/something in a way that shows that you feel no responsibility or respect for them
to refuse to move back; to refuse to change your opinions

examples: Questions were coming at them thick and fast.

meanings.def: to eat little or no food for a period of time, especially for religious or medical reasons
examples: Muslims fast during Ramadan.
During Ramadan they fast from dawn to sunset.

meanings.def: a period during which you do not eat food, especially for religious or health reasons
examples: to go on a fast
to break (= end) your fast
All members of the religious community keep these fasts.
In the evening the people break their fast.
He observes the fast of Ramadan.
In Cyprus this soup is served on Easter morning to break the long Lenten fast.
